title: 108_hr756
content: The "Child Modeling Exploitation Prevention Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes findings related to child modeling exploitation. The Congress finds that exploitive child modeling, involving children in lascivious positions for pedophiles, is a form of abuse leading to physical and psychological harm. Exploitive child modeling involves direct interaction between the child model and the pedophile, leading to trust and belief in meeting privately. Convicted pedophiles often use child pornography or exploitive modeling to fuel their desires, putting children at risk of abduction, abuse, or murder. Exploitive exhibitions of children are unacceptable by social standards and cause direct harm to the children involved. SEC. 3 prohibits employment in exploitive child modeling. Prohibition on employing child models in exploitive child modeling under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, with penalties for violations including fines or imprisonment up to 10 years. Exploitive child modeling defined as using a child under 17 for financial gain without marketing a product or service. Applies regardless of the child's employment relationship. The Fair Labor Standards Act prohibits oppressive child labor, including the employment of minors in violation of specific sections. Penalties for violations can include fines or imprisonment up to 10 years. SEC. 4. EXPLOITIVE CHILD MODELING OFFENSE. Section 2252B of title 18, United States Code, prohibits displaying or offering images of exploitive child modeling for financial gain in interstate or foreign commerce, with penalties of fines or imprisonment up to 10 years. Exceptions apply for images with serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value. Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section after section 2252A. Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section after section 2252A regarding exploitive child modeling.
